question: I wondered why he wasn't at school. Would it help if I came to see him? He's always seemed a good kid to me. Of course. I'll phone and we can fix a time.
answer: Ben! Ben! Mrs. Coetzee. She looked worried.

question: She's having trouble with her boy. He won't come to school.
answer: So you said you'd have a word with him?

question: Yes! She smiles and walks him to the car affectionately. Gordon! What are you doing here?
answer: That's not why I'm complaining, Mister Ben, sir. If he did wrong, I'd beat him myself. But he didn't. He did nothing and they wouldn't listen. They wouldn't believe him.

question: I'm sorry, Gordon. But there must be a reason.
answer: He says he wasn't doing anything wrong, Mister Ben, sir. And I believe him, I know my son! It's an injustice!

question: What about the court? Didn't he state his case?
answer: What does he know about court? Before he knew, it was all over.

question: I don't think there is anything we can do about it now. Outside, peering through the half-opened door, is Johan, shocked at what he sees. Ben tapes Jonathan on the head, he pulls up his shorts painfully, yet fiercely, anxious to cover himself up again.
answer: We can get a lawyer to appeal.

question: I'll be out in a minute.
answer: You don't understand, Mister Ben, sir. I don't want him to have a police record. It will be there for the rest of his life and make it difficult for him to get a job in the future.

question: Don't worry, Gordon. I'm sure there'll be no record, it's such a minor case. Please don't worry. Ben calls Johan from the outside. Johan, get some iodine from the cupboard.
answer: I'm not worried about the wounds. They'll heal in time, Mister Ben, sir. It's the wounds here. I worry about. Injustice... it festers. Johan comes back with a small bottle of medicine.

question: Disappeared? He's a child -- why didn't you tell me? Gordon just looks at him, sadly, patiently. Okay! I'll see what I can find out. Our gardener, yes. Probably nothing, but he's worried.
answer: ... And when was this? Ngubene -- Jonathan Ngubene. I'll get on to them straight away... Not at all -- I think better this time of morning -- after lunch, man, I'm a zombie. Sure -- let you know straight away -- love to, Susan... Cheers! Freda! Open an account... Du Toit. Benjamin Du Toit... Subject... Jonathan Ngubene. ... Freda -- I said no calls... Oh... Right... put them through. Hallo! Yes! How are you?... that is correct. Very well. Thank you for finally letting us know. He replaces the receiver... looks at it for a long second ... before lifting his eyes to the client. Sorry. He dials a number.

question: Hello, Dan... No... it's all right...
answer: I'm sorry. They have just officially informed me. The boy was never in detention. He died ... the day of the riots and as nobody came to claim the corpse he was buried a month ago.

question: Thanks a lot, Dan... I'll tell Gordon. 'Bye. Ben hangs up and stays there... thinking... until the BELL snaps him out of his thoughts.
answer: Mister Ben, sir. If it was me, all right. And if it was Emily, all right. We are not young. But he's out child. My time and your time, it's passing. But the time of our children is coming. And now if they kill our children -- if we let them -- what is it that we lived for?

question: What can we do, Gordon? You or I... We can't change it.
answer: That day, Mr. Ben, sir, when they whipped Jonathan, you also said we can do nothing. But if we had... if someone heard what we had to say this would not have happened.

question: It's a terrible thing, Gordon -- God knows I'm sorry. But you have other children to live for... I'll help them too with their schooling.
answer: How did he die, Mister Ben, sir?

question: I told you, Gordon... He died on the day of the riots.
answer: That's what they say. But I got to know for certain. How can I have peace? I must know how my son died and where they buried him.

question: Gordon. The police -- if they've said...
answer: I don't care what they say. He is my child. God is my witness today

question: ... This business of Gordon's son. Be careful, Ben. These are not normal times -- one has to make allowances.
answer: Don't worry! I'm no crusader. I've known Gordon a long time, that's all.

question: I understand -- it's your Christian duty to your neighbor.
answer: Something like that -- yes.

question: Coffee! Come on, Johan. Time for bed. Johan pulls back from his father's arms.
answer: Yes, son. Go and get some sleep. The boy nods and leaves.

question: I'm proud of you, Ben... what you've done for that family. But darling, you shouldn't take these things to heart so much. What more can you do about it?
answer: I don't know. I'm just tired, I suppose.

question: Come, come to bed. Her housecoat has fallen open. He lifts his face to hers and kisses her.
answer: I will, in a minute. I'll just put the thoughts of Standar Six away. They mustn't be lost to posterity. All right, time up! Hand in your test. Moans from the students. What's happened, Emily?

question: Come in, Mr. Du Toit, come in. How do you do? They shake. He's a large, friendly man, ruddy face, gray crew cut.
answer: Nice to meet you, Colonel Viljoen.

question: I used to watch you play for the Transvaal. You were one of the great wing forwards.
answer: Long time ago.

question: Come in. Captain Stolz, Mr. Du Toit. Do sit down. All right now, Gordon Ngubene.
answer: Well... to put it simply, Colonel...

question: I'm always grateful for that.
answer: I thought there might have been some kind of misunderstanding I could help straighten out.

question: Like what?
answer: I know him, Colonel. He works at my school. He's done work for me too.

question: And you feel you know him enough to vouch for him.
answer: Yes, after so many years... 10 years. Gordon's not the type to get himself in trouble. He's an honest, hard-working, church- going man.

question: Ha! You'd be surprised how many honest, decent, church-going men we come across during a working day. It's routine, Mr. Du Toit -- a routine enquiry. Cleaning up these townships we must leave no stone unturned.
answer: I appreciate that -- but Gordon would never...

question: Not an easy task either -- the press screaming blue murder -- especially the English. And they'll be the first to squeal if the Reds took over, make no mistake. Rushing back overseas clutching their bloody British passports. Have you any idea what will happen here if we don't follow every lead? We have a duty -- obligation. You have your job -- we have ours.
answer: Colonel -- believe me, I'm with you all the way. But in this case -- I'm sure that in your worthy pursuit of the guilty you have, unwittingly, involved the innocent. After all, we're all human. We all make mistakes sometimes. Viljoen laughs again.

question: We are indeed, Mr. Du Toit -- we are indeed. Though there's many who might need persuading as to that fact. Then... authority. Mr. Du Toit. While you're here, would you mind if I asked you a few questions about Ngubene?
answer: Colonel, I'd welcome it.

question: Good! Shall we start with his son?
answer: Jonathan.

question: The eldest.
answer: Yes. He died some time ago. Viljoen doesn't react.

question: What do you know about Gordon's activities since Jonathan's death?
answer: Nothing, Colonel.

question: Did Gordon ever discuss the death with you?
answer: Of course he did -- he was upset. The Colonel pauses.

question: But he accepted the truth?
answer: He is a religious man... in the end he would have resigned himself to it.

question: Would have? You mean he didn't? Was he angry? Rebellious?
answer: Come on, Colonel! If one of your kids died... ... and nobody would tell you how it happened or where his body is buried, wouldn't you be upset?

question: You have a son, Mr. Du Toit? The Colonel looks up at him... the first sign of steel in his eyes... then back to the papers. Does he burn and destroy -- everything he can lay his hands on?... No -- and neither does mine. That's what I can't understand... after everything the government does for them. Think about it, Mr. Du Toit. We're for you, not against you.
answer: I've never doubted it, Colonel. It's you who appear to be doubting me. These questions. You're making me feel like a criminal. There's a moment's pause -- then a burst of laughter.

question: I'm sorry, Mr. Du Toit... I'm sorry. It's force of habit. Once a policeman, always a policeman, eh? More laughter -- Ben joins in. Viljoen stands, signalling an end to the meeting. ... As soon as we're satisfied he's innocent, he will be released. We know what we're doing, Mr. Du Toit. You want your wife and that boy of yours to sleep safe tonight, don't you?
answer: One last favor, Colonel?

question: Fire away!
answer: Gordon's wife -- she's very worried. May she bring him some food and a change of clothes while he's still here?

question: No problem! Thank you for your help...
answer: Thank you. I'll rely on you, then.

question: Will you find your way out?
answer: I think so. And thanks. I feel much happier now.

question: Good! And give my regards to your father-in-law -- tell him we'll have a drink sometime -- maybe go to a game.
answer: I will. Goodbye.

question: I talked to them. Gordon will be released soon. The colonel was very understanding.
answer: Did you see Gordon?

question: No.
answer: Did they say anything about Jonathan?

question: Is that right, Papa?
answer: That's right, Suzette. But, only one detainee

question: Our Gordon?
answer: That's right.

question: My God. What on earth for? Susan leaves the kitchen without a word, with the dessert plates on the tray to the dining room. It must be a mistake, Papa.
answer: Of course it is. I went down there, told them. They're looking into it.

question: Went down where?
answer: John Vorster Square.

question: You old devil you. Does Ma know?
answer: No. And you're not going to tell her.

question: Be careful. I don't want my favorite Papa in trouble, Gordon or no Gordon.
answer: More wine? Viviers?

question: It's all right. Viviers returns to his seat as Ben shuts the door behind him. Oh, it's you... hum... Stanley, isn't it? That's all right, darling.
answer: A Friday night, man! I'm no doctor, I'm not on standby all the bloody time. Can't they wait 'til Monday?

question: Dan! I'm standing here with Gordon's clothing in my hand. It's bloodstained... There are broken teeth in the pocket. Monday may be too late! The lawyer has been banned.
answer: Do you mean Julius Nqakula? Too bad, he's a good lawyer. Why are you getting so involved, Ben?

question: A hard worker? I had to get rid of him. Susan doesn't react. She leaves to join the womens' group.
answer: What?

question: I fired him a few days before he was arrested for staying away from work for days. And for the sake of the school I say good riddance.
answer: What do you mean 'good riddance'?

question: That was a small taste of 'Samson.' We have a whole day... A knock at the door. ... Kom! A black policeman in uniform. JOHNSON SEROKE, enters with a letter in his hand. What do you want?
answer: A letter for you, Captain. Stolz goes to take the letter and turns to place it on his desk. He notices Seroke still standing.

question: What are you bloody-well waiting for?
answer: No reply, Captain?

question: Why didn't you tell me you'd been down to John Vorster Square?
answer: What difference would it have made?

question: I'm your wife, damn it!
answer: I didn't want to upset you.

question: Upset me? It upsets me when you share your bloody secrets with a child! Johan is embarrassed. Ben glances at him. Johan shrugs and shakes his head "not me." Ben planes on. Ben! Ben! Look at me for God sakes! Johan uit met jou! Johan leaves.
answer: Now what?

question: We have a good life. We may not have everything we might have had if...
answer: ... If I'd been more ambitious.

question: Ben, what's happening? Sometimes it seems to me I don't know you.
answer: What's happening -- it's something I've never had to face -- deal with -- before.

question: He's the gardener for God's sake, not one of the family.
answer: Be patient with me... When Gordon is free you'll have me all to yourself again... promise.

question: Ben. We're growing old.
answer: Nonsense. One's as old as he feels. I feel young and very attractive. I can still do my duty. She smiles up at him, chuckles, and then they kiss.

question: Gordon's dead.
answer: What? The news leaves Ben speechless. Stanley continues in flat, emotionless tones.

question: The bastards say he committed suicide... hanged himself.
answer: Suicide... is that what they told Emily -- poor woman...

question: They didn't tell her. She heard it on the radio like the rest of us. I contacted Lewinson immediately. He then rung the police to ask why Emily wasn't informed. Would you believe it, they said they were sorry, and they didn't know where to contact her. Ben walks slowly out of the garage in deep thoughts -- Stanley follows him.
answer: God! I never thought Gordon could commit suicide.

question: Did you understand me? I said, they said he committed suicide.
answer: How do we know?

question: Gordon wasn't a coward.
answer: Yes, but...

question: What do you mean 'but'? What about Timol who they said had jumped from a top-floor window? What about Ngudle? What about Mosala? Joyi? Malele? They all died in that John Vorster Square. All suicide, eh? Ben stares at him. There is something like a strange silence between them. Ben is confused and Stanley is staring at him. Ben breaks this embarrassing mood.
answer: Anything I can do to help?

question: He's got brothers.
answer: Brothers?

question: I'm his brother, man, we all are! We'll take care of everything. That's the African way.
answer: Stanley, I'd like to see Gordon.

question: Don't look for trouble, man. You know there are riots all over Soweto. You're out of it. Why don't you stay out?
answer: Don't you understand? I've got to go.

question: You got to go? Of course, Lanie... the last farewell. But we have to be careful. We expected it.
answer: How can you talk like that!?

question: A guy gets picked up by the S.B... he's part of history, man.
answer: You mean you had no hope, you didn't believe he'd be released?

question: Hope's a white word, Lanie... It's not hope we need.
answer: Well, thank God Emily has you to lean on, Stanley.

question: Emily is like my sister... We go back many years.
answer: Do you belong to the xhosa tribe too?

question: I am an African. That's all! Comprende?
answer: I am an African too! Stanley turns abruptly.

question: What?
answer: I was fourteen before I wore shoes -- except for church... I grew up on a plaas miles from any town... watching sheep and...

question: Bullshit! Next you'll have me believing we grew up in the same country, same laws, same freedom, same everything! We are now about to leave the white jungle and entering the land of love and glory. The car approaches a huge perimeter notice:
answer: So this is Soweto.

question: Land of love and glory, Lanie! But watch out for the police and army. They're patrolling all the time. Hurry up, Lanie. No sweets today. I'm sorry, babies. The children give Stanley a coy disbelieving look as they watch him go with the "white man." 'The living close the eyes of the dead. The dead open the eyes of the living.'
answer: Please, take me to Emily.

question: Look, we'd took one hell of a chance to get here, let's not push it.
answer: I really have to see her, Stanley. Stanley drives off.

question: I said don't push it. I have to keep you alive. What's more the house is full of mourners. What are your thoughts now?
answer: What do you mean?

question: Come on. I know you came to see the body. What do you think now?
answer: I... I cannot think. I'm confused.

question: You either believe what you saw or maybe you still prefer the government version.
answer: For Christ sake, just get off my back, Stanley.

question: Okay. It was a simple question. Stanley turns his RADIO ON and BANTU MUSIC invades the car as it speeds away in a cloud of dust. You know, Lanie, when you run a taxi, especially a pirate taxi like me, you have eyes and ears everywhere. Even when a policeman farts in his bed you know. People want a reference book, a permit to stay in Soweto, a house, anything, we taxi drivers know the routes. I'll tell you something... Shit!
answer: What?

question: Dr. Hassiem has been picked up.
answer: Who's he?

question: Dr. Hassiem is the doctor we got to represent Emily at Gordon's autopsy. We wanted the truth. Ben suddenly realizes the significances.
answer: He would have testified. Bloody hell!

question: A smart move by your Boer brothers. They have silenced Hassiem.
answer: His report has to be important. We can only use what we have. Therefore, Lewinson must get a very good advocate. If only we could get hold of this Hassiem's report.

question: What's the use? It's one big game and we blacks are merely spectators. Hey Lanie, can one be a spectator as he's being kicked around? He laughs.
answer: It's not a question of being spectators. The courts are impartial, the law is what matters.

question: That's what you all say. I have to move man. Your neighbors! Now, be careful. They will put their marks on you!
answer: Who?

question: You'll find out! In case you need me. Don't give your name -- just say 'Lanie' phoned -- right? Ben gets out of the car.
answer: Now tomorrow at ten...

question: Sharp! At our smart liberal friend's office, yeh!
answer: Good night. Stanley drives vigorously away. I went to Soweto and saw Gordon's body. They have lied to me, my own people -- they killed him! I saw the body.

question: Please sit down. Take this chair, the other one is broken.
answer: I didn't mean to disturb you. I've come to talk to you.

question: Yes, it's good. What I want to know is why did they kill him. He didn't do them nothing. You know, Mr. Ben, sir, I washed his whole body for he was my husband. And I know a man who killed himself, he doesn't look like that.
answer: I'm sure. Robert walks in, looks at Ben and walks into his bedroom to fetch something, then as he's about to go out:

question: You have to understand what's happening to our children today, they're like wasps when you burn their nest.
answer: Emily, I have really come to assure you that I will do all I can to help you find out what really happened to Jonathan and your husband -- we cannot bring them back to life, but we can make sure that this sort of thing won't ever happen again.

question: You mean well, sir, but it's better to forgive. If we keep the pain alive then hate and bitterness will remain with us.
answer: The air must be cleared. So we can breathe again.

question: I'm pleased I came.
answer: Wait, let me check the situation. He opens the door and walks out. Take it easy. It's okey, dokey, but hurry.

question: Do I...
answer: Yes, on the floor man. Stanley opens the back door for Ben. Who crouches on the floor. Okay. Kids, time to go home. Be careful.

question: Are we still in Soweto?
answer: Why don't you look for yourself? Ben rises and sees that they're at least a mile out. He is not amused.

question: What the hell are you playing at?
answer: Precautions, Lanie.

question: Don't call me Lanie! What does that mean anyway?
answer: You will not understand, Lanie. They drive off.

question: Dr. Jansen, you are a state pathologist of many years standing and I have no doubt a well-qualified pathologist. Could you now please tell us what caused the death of the deceased?
answer: I found that death had been caused by the application of force to the neck, consistent with hanging.

question: You are sure about the hanging? This pressure on the neck, could it also have been exerted in other ways?
answer: It could, but it is not for me to speculate.

question: Of course not, Doctor. The list of injuries found on the body was horrifyingly long; bruises, swellings, abrasions, broken rib, lacerations, etc. How long before death do you estimate he received these injuries?
answer: I couldn't say exactly.

question: Roughly.
answer: Some were fourteen to twenty days old, others three to four days and others even more recent.

question: Even more recent. I see. I understand you had a Dr. Hassiem present at the autopsy.
answer: That's correct.

question: There were two reports, ours and his. Did they tally?
answer: Yes, it was. In most respects.

question: Isn't it normal practice to have one report? Why did Dr. Hassiem decide to draw up a separate report? If he really co-signed yours.
answer: That's for him to answer!

question: I would very much like to, Dr. Jansen, but he's been detained -- you know of course that he represented the Ngubene family. Thank you. There's a murmur around the court... Ben looks across at Viljoen who returns his gaze -- smiling.
answer: the police physician, giving evidence.

question: Dr. Herzog, did you examine the deceased?
answer: Yes, one day Captain Stolz called me in. The man had toothache.

question: That's all?
answer: As far as I could tell -- yes. Why should I? The man was perfectly healthy, just complaining of toothache. I extracted three decayed teeth, and gave him aspirin for the pain... that's all.

question: Did the captain or anyone else assist you during the examination?
answer: I... I cannot remember.

question: Thank you, Your Worship. I'd like to call Captain Stolz. There's a buzz from the spectators as Captain Stolz walks up to the witness stand. He's given a Bible. You're a police officer stationed at John Vorster Square?
answer: That's right, Your Worship.

question: You arrested Gordon Ngubene. Could you describe what happened?
answer: Acting on information we had received, I went to the house of the deceased, accompanied by Lieutenant Venter, Lieutenant Botha, and three native members of the security force. This was about 10 P.M. I informed Ngubene that he was under arrest under Article 6 of the Terrorism Act. He then became violent and resisted arrest. A certain force had to be applied to restrain him. We found several incriminating documents. These pointed to his involvement with the A.N.C. and activities endangering the security of the state.

question: Was the deceased ever assaulted to your knowledge?
answer: Never. He was always treated with courtesy and correctness. But, one time we had cause to use force against him. It was the day before his death. The deceased suddenly showed signs of aggression. He tried to jump through the open window of my office. He was acting like a mad man. It took six of my men to restrain him, and he had to be manacled hand and foot, for his own safety. But once he calmed down, he was ready to make a statement about his activities. The next morning we found him dead in his cell.

question: Thank you, Your Worship. Captain Stolz, you said you treated the deceased always with courtesy and correctness, then how do you account for the injuries found on the body?
answer: Sometimes detainees deliberately injure themselves for propaganda purposes. The gallery screams its objections. Stanley leans forward and grins across the partition at Ben. The Magistrate warns the crowd. Finally the gallery quiets down.

question: You say he tried to jump out of the open window... Are there no bars to prevent such an act?
answer: They had been removed for repair.

question: And why did he wish to jump out? Because you were torturing him?
answer: He wasn't tortured.

question: Perhaps it was the toothache then. You said you seized incriminating documents at the deceased's home; can you produce them to see how subversive he was?
answer: Those documents cannot be introduced as evidence, Your Worship, in view of the fact that state security is involved.

question: I put it to you, Captain -- that the only subversive activities the deceased had been involved in were his efforts to establish what happened to his son, Jonathan, allegedly shot during a riot, although several witnesses are prepared to testify that he died in detention one month later.
answer: I protest...

question: This would support my case that an innocent man has died in your hands under highly questionable circumstances.
answer: If it please Your Worship... this unwarranted slur on the integrity of the special branch is unacceptable... and based, I may say, on allegations which are in any case irrelevant to the present inquest.

question: Captain Stolz lied. My husband never fight the police when he was arrested. They were rough with him, pushing him and threatening.
answer: When your husband's clothes were given to you, in what condition were they?

question: There was blood on them and in the back pocket I found three broken teeth.
answer: Now Mrs. Ngubene, you have seen the note that's said to have been written by your husband. Do you recognize the writing?

question: That's not how my husband writes. He never wrote that letter, they lie.
answer: Thank you, Mrs. Ngubene.

question: I'd like to call my last witness. Grace Nkosi. Were you ever detained?
answer: Yes sir, at John Vorster Square.

question: For how long?
answer: Six months.

question: Can you tell us what happened to you during that time?
answer: I was interrogated by many special policemen, but mainly Captain Stolz and the one they call Venter. As they were searching somebody I know, they wanted me to tell them where that person was hidden. As I refuse to cooperate they beat me with a sjambok. After some time I fell and they kicked me in the face and stomach. I spot blood and they try to make me lick it. Then Captain Stolz threw a wet towel and started twisting it around my neck... ... until I lost consciousness. They did this several time and the last one Captain Stolz said 'come on meid, speak up, or do you want to die like Gordon Ngubene?' A few days later I was released. ON Melanie taking notes.

question: I'm sorry, Emily.
answer: Fuck off. The press is still pursuing them.

question: My car is over there.
answer: Never mind your car. Let's get away from these vultures. By the way, I'm Melanie Bruwer.

question: Obviously of the Rand Daily Mail. I read your article about Jonathan.
answer: Ten out of ten, Mr. Du Toit. I know about you too.

question: You do? Melanie smiles.
answer: We have a mutual friend. One Stanley.

question: I remember. The mortuary in Soweto... ... The ambiguous Stanley.
answer: Stanley? No. Just careful. A big black rough uncut diamond. Don't be fooled by his happy-go- lucky attitude. There's much more to him.

question: He couldn't have given you a glowing report of me. I'm sorry, but where are we going?
answer: I thought a cooling drink at my house.

question: Mrs. Bruwer, I'm not...
answer: I promise you. I'm not after an interview or anything like that. She smiles.

question: I really must go home.
answer: Please, Mr. Du Toit, and you'll meet my darling father. She smiles again. A disarming smile. There he is by the eucalyptus tree, on the left. That's old Bruwer.

question: How long have you lived here?
answer: Oh, about twenty-one years. I love this house.

question: Oh, about twenty-one years. I love this house.
answer: Is that you, Melanie?

question: Of course, Dad. I want you to meet a friend.
answer: Does anyone have a friend nowadays?

question: Mr. Du toit, Dad.
answer: Do you like bees?

question: Be careful, I can see philosophy coming.
answer: You shut up. Let me tell you about bees, and for that matter ants

question: What about individuality, Dad?
answer: There's the rub, my girl. There's the rub. One of these days I'll ask the bees. I'm sure they have the answer. Now, you two run along!

question: A drink, Dad?
answer: I've been peeing too much this morning.

question: That's my Daddy. Melanie and Ben enter the house. Now you see in what environment I was spawned. Ben looks at the shelves and smiles. Please sit down, on that chair. That's Dad's. Drink?
answer: Please. A...

question: A brandy?
answer: No thanks, a beer will be fine.

question: The mugs are the few things that Dad brought from Germany. He studied philosophy in Tubingen and Berlin before the last war.
answer: I thought they were German? Melanie sits, her legs propped up on the settee, hugging her knees.

question: Mr. Du Toit, tell...
answer: Please, call me Ben.

question: All right, Ben, tell me, why are you so depressed? You really expect a different verdict?
answer: Why do you ask? Can you understand it?

question: Of course I understand it. What could they have. I'm not cynical. I'm only trying to be realistic.
answer: Tell me, Miss Bruwer...

question: Ben and Melanie, that's fair.
answer: Tell me, do you believe in the notion of justice?

question: I'll never stop believing. But in this country I've learned it's pointless to look for it in certain situations.
answer: What use is a system if justice does not apply to all situations?

question: Exactly. And you cannot fight for justice unless you know injustice very well. You've got to know your enemy first.
answer: That's a tall order

question: Did you enjoy the 'bobotie?' When I heard the verdict on the news I knew you'd be upset. I wanted to make you something special.
answer: Thank you, darling.

question: I'm glad it's all over. You take things to heart too much. Ben comes and stands behind Susan -- looking at her through the mirror.
answer: They killed Gordon -- first they kill Jonathan, and then him. How can they get away with it?

question: Now come on, Ben. Gordon's death upset me, too. But the Magistrate had all the facts. He must know what he's doing, he's had years of experience. The case has run its course, and nobody can do anything more about it! It's all over and done with.
answer: I'm not so sure about that, Susan!

question: I'm damned well sure! It's over, Ben! You better get that into your head. Ben just stares at her with seething anger. She stands up and starts being hysterical. A teacher, always a bloody teacher. You never moved yourself for us. But for the blacks, oh yes. Whose side are you on, Ben? And I'm sick and tired of those natives coming here. Why don't you bloody well go and live in Soweto? Now where are you going?
answer: Soweto! Then shuts the door behind him. More meneer Van de Merwe. Our boys gave the Eastern province a thrashing. Is anything wrong? And a packet of tobacco and pipe cleaners. The man gets them and takes a note from Ben and gives him his change. By then a man is waiting. See you tomorrow.

question: Soweto! Then shuts the door behind him. More meneer Van de Merwe. Our boys gave the Eastern province a thrashing. Is anything wrong? And a packet of tobacco and pipe cleaners. The man gets them and takes a note from Ben and gives him his change. By then a man is waiting. See you tomorrow.
answer: Now, Papa, this is going too far! How could you?

question: How's that, Suzette?
answer: You didn't stop to think of the family. Poor mother, how can she face anyone? And tomorrow is Sunday!

question: You listen, Papa, just tell me, why?
answer: Do you really think I specially arranged for the photographers to take that picture? And what's more it's distorted.

question: What's distorted about it? Your face is practically touching that meid's face, like you were about to kiss her.
answer: Suzette, pull yourself together!

question: Today the whole country has seen that photograph. We, your children, are going to suffer. At this very moment Chris is negotiating with the Provincial Council. Would you like to see them cancel it? You have no feeling, Papa!
answer: Suzette!

question: Who?... I don't know you and have nothing to say to you... No thank you for your advice! He puts the phone down. The PHONE RINGS again. Ben picks it up and waits. It's you, Viviers... I appreciate it... of course... Not yet... Any thank you. Tot siens. Morning, Mr. Cloete... I'd like to say... ... Mr. Cloete, may I ask what on earth has the picture to do with politics?... I'm sorry Mr. Cloete, I have to go.
answer: Everything was examined in depth in court.

question: Did you read the papers, Dominee? Were you happy with what came to light? And is it the Magistrate's work to pretend that the facts which came to light didn't exist?
answer: Was it really facts, Ben? Just then the African "HERDBOY" walks up to them taking off his lattered greasy hat. Ja? What is it Tom? Later, Tom. I bought a bull last week.

question: I know, Gordon. What they said about him, that he was plotting against the government -- is a downright lie. He was only doing what I would have done as a father; searching for his son.
answer: No one but God can see what's in our hearts. Isn't it presumptuous to pretend we can speak for someone else?

question: Have you no faith in your fellow men, Dominee? Don't you love your neighbor?
answer: Wait a minute, instead of criticizing blindly, don't you think we have reason to be proud of the judiciary we have? suppose this had been Russia; what do you think would have happened then?

question: What's the use of reaching a court when a handful of people have all the power to decide what is going to be said in that court and by whom? The one man they allowed to speak for himself, that young Archibald Chigorimbo, didn't he immediately deny everything they forced him to say in his statement? And the girl who spoke of her own torture? That did not refer to our situation in this South Africa. Do you know what I believe in, Dominee, that once in one's life, just once, one should have enough faith in something to risk everything for it.
answer: One can gain the world and still lose one's soul. Tea must be ready. Bester and Ben walk towards the house still in conversation.

question: I hope you don't mind us talking here.
answer: I don't mind, Mr. Cloete.

question: I'll come to the point. You can't imagine how shocked I was by that scandalous photograph in the Ossewa.
answer: The woman lost her husband, she was shattered with grief.

question: A Kaffir woman, Du Toit.
answer: I can't see that it makes any difference.

question: Good afternoon, Professor.
answer: Melanie isn't home. You are...

question: Ben Du Toit. You have a nice vegetable garden.
answer: You mean the area or the produce?

question: Both. What plants are these?
answer: What's the world coming to? It's herbs, can't you see? Thyme there, oregano over there, feunel next to the tomatoes, sage here and rosemary somewhere. Poor plants, they re not in their ideal soil or climate. Next time, I'll bring some soil from the mountain of Zeus. Perhaps the old man's holiness will do the trick. Come, you are just the person to sample my greengage wine. I don't suppose you've ever tasted it? I'm sure I'm the only person in the country making greengage wine. He leads Ben to the two old chairs by the back wall. He enters the kitchen and returns with a bottle of greengage wine and two glasses. The first bottle this year, and you don't have to tell me if you like it or not. Tell me, did you ever study philosophy?

question: Not really. I've read a few books.
answer: Not bad, in fact quite good. Now where was I... Oh, I was going to say after decades of philosophy, I find myself being forced back to the earth. Do you know, Ben, we're all living in the spell of abstractions. Hitler, apartheid, the great American dream, the lot?

question: What about Jesus?
answer: Misunderstood. You don't have to finish it.

question: It's quite nice.
answer: Melanie has told me a little about you. It's not an easy road you have chosen.

question: I feel I have no choice.
answer: Of course you have a choice. Damn it. One always has a choice. Only thank God you made the choice you did. But all I want to say is, keep your eyes open, young man.

question: That's encouraging.
answer: We are both Boers, Ben. We know how hard our people worked to get a toehold on this land; it was a good life. Now look at the mess. It's all systems and no God! Sooner or later people start believing in their way of life as an absolute

question: What you say is very interesting and important.
answer: Take for example the way the government is handling the electorate; like a bloody donkey. Carrot in front and kick at the backside. The carrot is apartheid, Dogma. The kick is quite simply, fear. Black peril, red peril, whatever name you want to give it. Fear can be a wonderful ally, Ben. I talk too much, I always do with younger people, they don't fall asleep to me.

question: We Afrikaners have to stop to turn a blind eye and look around us and at ourselves.
answer: You are right. We still have time. History should teach us about those who regarded themselves as the chosen people.

question: Professor Bruwer, may I say I have needed to hear somebody say some of the things you said. I still have hope for our country.
answer: If you lose that you have lost everything. I'll get back to the earth.

question: Thank you.
answer: I'll tell that hot-head daughter of mine that you came to see her. Ben takes his leave.

question: There is absolutely no doubt that they were killed in custody. Those responsible must be punished, whoever they are, or whatever their rank.
answer: The problem is laying our hands on them.

question: Tell me, Dan, we lost at the inquest, what next?
answer: The family can file a civil claim.

question: What does that entail?
answer: To put it briefly, it means we have to have witnesses, affidavits and any information relating to the arrest and death of Gordon. We also need similar information on Jonathan. You see Ben, for example, Stolz figures in both cases. That's one link at least.

question: I know what I have to do.
answer: I didn't think you would want to have anything to do with me after that crap in the Ossewa.

question: Why? You didn't write it.
answer: I'm a journalist, perhaps tarred with the same brush.

question: No.
answer: So what happened? I can imagine. The family, the dominee, colleagues, neighbors...

question: A distorted photograph and a few poisoned words and meneer Du Toit is a leper. That's why I called on you the other day, I needed to talk to somebody rational.
answer: Thanks for the compliment. But remember, you're an Afrikaner, you're one of them. In their eyes they regard you as the worst kind of traitor.

question: You are an Afrikaner too, and your articles, in a liberal English paper?
answer: My mother was a foreigner, I'm not pure, wragte Afrikaner. They don't expect the same loyalty from me that they demand from you.

question: What kind of loyalty? Blind loyalty. Until the deaths of Jonathan and Gordon, I gave all the loyalty I could give, laager loyalty. You know, Melanie, we Afrikaners have always lived in our laager, we have not seen what's beyond the mountains.
answer: Has it ever occurred to you that the Volk may be scared to leave the laager? That's the downfall of this country. So, where do you go from here?

question: We carry on. There has to be justice.
answer: Justice.

question: We lost at the inquest, so we pursue them in a civil action. I consulted the attorney Dan Lewinson.
answer: We know each other well.

question: Mr. Du Toit, if you knew what we're working with every day of our lives, and what we're up against, you would understand why we have to be so thorough.
answer: However you go about it.

question: I can understand you're upset about having your house searched ... but...
answer: I wasn't thinking about myself.

question: What are you talking about then, Mr. Du Toit?
answer: My thoughts, Captain, I'm sure, are an open book to you.

question: An interesting book -- Picasso -- Not one I'm familiar with.
answer: Not on your list of banned books, Captain?

question: I'm getting tired of the trek to Cape Town and then back to Pretoria. If I had my way, Parliament and government would be in the same city. There's nothing wrong with Pretoria.
answer: I thought you'd prefer Cape Town; the sea and Table Mountain.

question: That's for holidays. Anyway, Ben, one of the reasons for this visit was that I wanted to have a discussion with you.
answer: What about?

question: It's that photograph in the papers. Ben, a thing like that could be an embarrassment for someone who is a member of Parliament. It's a grievous day when one's family's behavior comes between him and his duty to the fatherland.
answer: Are you blaming me for trying to help those people?

question: I've been doing that all my life, be they black or white. But no member of our family has been seen with a Kaffir woman before, Ben.
answer: I am glad you mentioned it, Father. Because I'd like to discuss the whole thing with you. First, there's the matter of Gordon Ngubene himself.

question: What about him? I thought the case was closed.
answer: The inquest didn't clear up half of what happened.

question: Oh, really?
answer: We have no irrefutable evidence yet, but we have enough to indicate that something serious is being covered up.

question: You're jumping to conclusions, Ben.
answer: I know what I'm talking about. The black waiter places the drinks on the table.

question: All right, Ben, I'm listening. Perhaps I can use my influence. But you'll have to convince me first.
answer: If they have really nothing to hide, why is the special branch going out of its way to intimidate me.

question: What's this about special branch?
answer: They raided the house; they are tapping my phone, and I have been threatened by one of the officers.

question: I'm sorry, Ben, I'd rather not have anything to do with this sort of thing.
answer: Why?

question: If the special branch are involved they must have good reasons.
answer: It's exactly what I said, Father, when Jonathan first got into trouble. Of course, they have good reasons

question: Ben, how could you side with the enemies of your people?
answer: You mean you're prepared to sit back and allow an injustice to be done.

question: It's you, Ben, who talk about injustice? A man who teaches history at school? Did you forget what our people have suffered under the English oppressors? Now that we have at along last come to power in our own land.
answer: Now we're free to do to others what they used to do to us. What will you do if you were a black man in this country today, Father?

question: Don't you realize what the government is doing for the blacks? It's a slow process, Ben. One of these days the whole bloody lot of them will be free and independent in their own parts of the land, the bantoustans -- what can be more just than that? But they're not ready yet. We have nothing to be ashamed of before the eyes of the world, my boy.
answer: We don't? I'm not sure we're going to survive.

question: African time.
answer: I'm sorry. They drive off towards Soweto.

question: Doesn't matter, Lanie -- as long we are on time for the revolution.
answer: The special branch searched my house four days ago.

question: The S.B. searches your house? Did they take anything?
answer: A few journals, letters -- nothing much. Just wanted to scare me, that's all.

question: Don't be so sure. They may think you're onto something big.
answer: They're not that stupid.

question: 'Lanie' -- don't you believe it -- nothing's as stupid as the old S.B. If they decide it's a bomb they're looking for, you can shove a turd in their face and they'll swear to God it's a bomb. He laughs... making Ben smile. And did they?
answer: What?

question: Scare you?
answer: No. They tried too hard. Stanley laughs again.

question: Hallelujah! Shake, man. Join the club. Did you hear that, Lanie? More kids dying?
answer: What's happening? What's the singing?

question: The first one two days after they took him away. And the other one came later.
answer: But, Emily, why didn't you tell me long ago?

question: I had given my word to the man -- who brought them to me --
answer: Emily, I have to meet the man.

question: He said he didn't want anybody to know who he is. I cannot make trouble for him in his work.
answer: He has to be persuaded. He is very important to us.

question: You mean Dr. Hassiem. How are you going to do that? You know of course that he is detained.
answer: I know, with luck they may release him.

question: With luck.
answer: But, Emily, this man is important, please try to tell him we will protect his identity. No one will know. Nothing will be done without his approval. I only want to talk to him.

question: You could help with the affidavits. Lewinson the lawyer has stressed their importance.
answer: We know each other. He's a good lawyer for this kind of case. Of course I'll do what I can. My commitment forces me.

question: I'm glad.
answer: How are you planning to safeguard the documents? Stanley told me you have already had a said by the S.B.

question: Let's hope so.
answer: I'll make some tea.

question: Not for me, Sis -- too strong for me. No whisky?
answer: In my house? You know better than that, Stanley.

question: I don't care! It doesn't hurt me! Susan stares at him, at Ben, turns abruptly, walks out of the room. Johan looks at his father. It was my friends, Dad. They're so stupid... They won't listen. They don't even want to know what you're trying to do. He's crying.
answer: Are you sure you know?

question: Yes. I know.
answer: Does it worry you?

question: Now you must be exaggerating, Mr. Du Toit.
answer: My house has been searched. My phone is tapped. My mail is opened. And last night three shots were fired through my window -- close to killing my wife. Viljoen reacts.

question: Mr. Du Toit, if shots were fired into your premises, we will investigate.
answer: All I want to know, Colonel, is why don't you leave me in peace?

question: Now wait, wait a minute, Mr. Du Toit, you're not trying to blame me?
answer: Tell me, Colonel, why is it so important to you people to stop my enquiries about Gordon Ngubene?

question: Is that what you are doing? Well, now. If you possess any information that may be of use to us, I trust you won't hesitate to discuss it with me. He leans forward towards Ben, his tone darkening. Because if there are facts you are deliberately hiding from us, Mr. Du Toit -- If you give us reason to believe that you may be involved in activities that may be dangerous to both yourself and us -- then I can foresee some problems.
answer: Is that a threat, Colonel?

question: Let's call it a warning. A friendly warning. For God's sake, open your eyes, Mr. Du Toit! Don't you see you're being used!
answer: By the Communists, I suppose. Goodbye, Colonel. I'm sure. He leaves. The colonel immediately picks up the phone.

question: By the Communists, I suppose. Goodbye, Colonel. I'm sure. He leaves. The colonel immediately picks up the phone.
answer: How's it? No trouble finding this place? You met Sadie. She's one of us. And this is Johnson Seroke. The man of the letters.

question: Johnson. A beer would be nice.
answer: You know they call this place Vrededorp, but we baptize it Malay Camp. Your first time in Malay Camp, Lanie?

question: I've driven through here many times.
answer: The main road, eh?

question: Ja.
answer: Sure, Sadie. And thank you. Can I help myself to another beer?

question: I know that. Tell me, what do you know about Gordon?
answer: Very little.

question: You did talk to him from time to time?
answer: He gave me the letters.

question: When was the last time you saw him?
answer: Just before he died.

question: Did you attend any of the interrogations?
answer: No. I'm not a member of the Special Branch. But once I had to deliver a letter to Capt. Stolz, Gordon was there.

question: It's very interesting. When was the last time you saw him?
answer: I saw them take the body away to the cells. He was limp.

question: You did! Johnson, why do you stay with the police? You don't really belong there.
answer: It's a job. And how can I go away? I love my family. He jumps up and faces Ben with a look of anger and panic. They must never know I told you anything. Right?

question: I understand. I promise.
answer: This is strictly between the three of us. Don't worry, man. Take it easy. Stanley goes to the cupboard for another beer. A beer, Lanie?

question: No, thank you. You know, Stanley, after what happened the other night I was about to give this whole thing up.
answer: What happened, man?

question: My wife nearly got killed. Three shots were fired into the house. What right have I to expose my family to harassment and actual physical danger? That's what I asked myself.
answer: Three bloody shots and you crawl on your hands and knees to people like Stolz, and say 'I give up.' What is the beginning for you is a version of what we suffer all our bloody life. Shit, I thought you had more guts than this, man!

question: I didn't say I'm giving up.
answer: But you thought about it.

question: Johnson has revived my determination.
answer: It's a hell of a time, Lanie, but we'll survive. You and me. I tell you!

question: You think we may still win in the end, Stanley?
answer: Of course not, Lanie -- but we needn't lose either -- what matters is to stick around. By the way, man, I'm off on a trip -- Botswana -- thought I'd tell you in case you get worried.

question: Why are you going there?
answer: Business. Tell you next week. Now for the bad news I've been saving to the last.

question: What?
answer: Julius has been arrested. He broke his banning order and visited his sister. You know what that means? At least a year's imprisonment.

question: A year in jail just for visiting his sister?
answer: That's the chance he took. And he'll be the last to complain.

question: Don't you think the real reason for this arrest was that they found out he was helping us?
answer: So what? Lanie, you're not getting guilt complexes now, are you? That's a luxury only liberals can afford. Julius will be back, man. All refreshed by a spell in the deep-freeze.

question: How can we shrug off a man we've been working with?
answer: Who said we're shrugging him off? Best way of remembering a man, Lanie, is to carry on fighting.

question: What about you?
answer: What?

question: I mean not married...
answer: And living in this chaos with my eccentric father? I love him and we get on perfectly. We have been together since I was a year old. My mother could not adapt to South Africa. She went back to London and we've never heard from her since.

question: Being a professor and bringing up a child, how did he manage that?
answer: Dorothy, dear Dorothy, she was a fantastic mother. In fact she had two families, me and her three children in Alexandra township.

question: And this little girl grew up to be a tough journalist. Why a journalist?
answer: Sometimes I ask myself the same question. She leans against the sink and picks up her mug of coffee. Alright. I'll tell you. I was brought up in a sheltered way, not that Dad was possessive, not openly anyway. I think he'd just seen enough of the mess the world was in, to want to protect me as much as he could. Then, I went to university. I don't know what you'll think... being a teacher.

question: About what?
answer: Then I married my ex-teacher.

question: Oh. He must have been young.
answer: Fifteen years difference. He too protected me like Dad. Then one day I visited Dorothy in Alexandra and saw her home and the appalling conditions in that township. I was shocked, Ben, and ashamed.

question: Go on. Melanie pours him another mug of coffee and starts to wipe up.
answer: That made me think that I was a parasite, something white and maggot-like... just a thing... a sweet and ineffectual thing. I felt more and more claustrophobic. Poor Brian, who loved and pampered me. Had no idea what was happening. I left him for a whole year and we divorced.

question: And then you became a journalist?
answer: I thought it would force me, or help me, to expose myself. To force me to see and to take notice of what was happening around me.

question: Did it work? She returns to the kitchen with a cigarette.
answer: I wish I could give you a straight answer. What did help me was my wanderings in Africa.

question: How did you manage that on a South African passport? We South Africans are white devils in Africa.
answer: My mother was English, remember? So I get a British passport. It comes in handy even for the paper.

question: You really are your father's daughter!
answer: I wonder what he's doing right now. Most likely standing on a rock, looking through his old binoculars at springbok or a lion or whatever. One of the two large CATS approaches them, tail in the air, and goes to Melanie, drubbing against her legs, PURRING luxuriously. She picks it up into her arms.

question: How often does he go on these trips to the veldt?
answer: It depends -- -- Bonjour, Ben. I'm Porto and my friend is Bello! Ben smiles and starts to caress Porto in Melanie's arms.

question: She's a widow, man. That's what happens in Soweto when a woman loses her man. They throw her out of the house and out of the city.
answer: Zululand! The whole thing smells of being an excuse to send her hundreds of miles from the case. And how will they live there?...

question: Shit! I was about to find her a place, but I had to go to look for Robert.
answer: So, that's why you went to Botswana for.

question: Sis Emily asked me but it was no use. His mind was made up. He was going to join Wellington in Zambia.
answer: Couldn't you stop him? He's a little boy, Stanley!

question: I have got to.
answer: Think of your heritage, man. My God -- think of your wife, your family, friends, neighbors. What's going to happened to them -- all of us -- if we can't depend on our own kind? We're educationalists -- teachers. We are building for the future.

question: Without simple justice we don't deserve a future.
answer: We're Boers, man -- Afrikaners. We are your nation. What's justice for us is justice -- period! Traitors like you are threatening centuries of Afrikaner sacrifice.

question: That last remark was slanderous -- I'm simply being faithful to the truth.
answer: Slanderous? My God, man, you slander a whole people. He walks silently through the office then continues. You have given me no alternative. I have to abide by the regulations of the Department of Education -- so I have made my report. And there will have to be a formal inquiry. But until such time...

question: It won't be necessary, Mr. Cloete. I'll send you my resignation.
answer: Thank you for making things much easier. Ben stares at him for a moment, then turns to leave. As he reaches the door, Cloete says: And it would be better if Johan left too. Ben turns to stare at him, amazed.

question: Are you serious?
answer: He's a Kaffir-lover too, isn't he? The color drains from Ben's face. Then he steps forward, slaps Cloete thunderously across the face, hurling him back into his chair, and strides out, leaving the door ajar.

question: Oom Ben, I was waiting for you. I have something interesting to tell you.
answer: Later, Viviers.

question: But, Oom Ben, it's about the S.B. they came to question me. Before they started questioning me I told them they were wasting their time. Ben doesn't react. They asked if I was cooperating with you. What I knew about the A.N.C. Can you imagine that! They then said
answer: I'm sorry, Viviers. I never wanted you to get involved. I have just resigned.

question: Lanie! Ever in your fucking life seen such a stampede, hah?
answer: Maybe you think it's funny, Stanley, but I don't. Do you realize what you've done? Come into the dining room. Stanley follows Ben slowly, swaying.

question: Jeez, who was that old cunt with the potbelly and black suit, looks like an undertaker?
answer: My father-in-law.

question: You joking! Shit! I fucked it all up for you. Sorry, man.
answer: Now pull yourself together, Stanley. It's not funny at all! What's the matter with you today? You're drunk and making an idiot of yourself. Say what you've come to say. Otherwise, go to hell! Stanley's laughter changes into a broad grin. He sur- veys the table and takes a bit of turkey from a plate and starts to eat it quietly.

question: Right. Dead right. Put the Kaffir in his place. Ben grabs him by the shoulders and starts to shake him.
answer: Bloody hell! Stanley, what's wrong with you?

question: Emily is dead.
answer: Emily dead? How? When? Stanley doesn't answer - he cries. What happened, Stanley? Oh, my God. Please tell me.

question: A broken heart. All they said.
answer: God. Through the window, he sees Suzette and Chris carrying suitcases, back down the path to his in-laws' car; Father-In-Law shepherding his wife and an ashen, dazed Susan, helping them into the car.

question: God. Through the window, he sees Suzette and Chris carrying suitcases, back down the path to his in-laws' car; Father-In-Law shepherding his wife and an ashen, dazed Susan, helping them into the car.
answer: They don't know what you've got and you're a danger to them. I know there's a point of no return, but with our system, one has to plot the route with care.

question: That's the main reason for coming here tonight. Melanie, I need your help. Without Emily, we can't pursue our civil suit. The only thing left open to us is to expose them through the press, and the media here and abroad.
answer: And your safety also, Ben, lies in the press. That way the world will know the brutality and power of our security services; here questions can be asked in Parliament. And the white public can appreciate the implications of the fascist laws of this country.

question: You know, Melanie, I'm discovering that the enemy is not in Soweto. The enemy is ourselves. Our bigotry, our laws, our system. We have our own fight and it's just beginning.
answer: We better win before the blacks have won. Ben and Melanie laugh.

question: Now, before going to the press, I have to have all the documents. I must have two vital affidavits; Dr. Hassiem's, he's detained and Jonathan's friend, Wellington has fled to Zambia.
answer: Zambia? I'm going to Rhodesia... I can go to Zambia.

question: Could you?
answer: And I can use my British passport. I know my way around Lusaka.

question: That would be very useful.
answer: This calls for a drink. Gin and tonic?

question: Please. As Melanie walks away, Ben looks at her with admiration and tenderness... her dress swinging around her legs... her bare feet soundless on the floor... the quiet grace of her movement. On the way to the kitchen to get the drinks, Melanie goes to the record player. There's a record already on the turntable. Melanie. Be careful.
answer: Of course, Ben. She goes into the kitchen. Cheers!

question: Do be careful. I wouldn't want you hurt. She reaches for his hand.
answer: Don't worry.

question: And hurry back. A new track starts on the RECORD.
answer: That's my favorite, Ben.

question: I can't dance.
answer: Rugger player? They laugh as they start to dance to the slow BLUES MUSIC. The laughing subsides as they hold each other closer. The dancing starts to lose the beat of the music. They look into each other's eyes and Ben envel- ops her tenderly in his arms hugging her as close as possible against him. They stop dancing. Ben kisses her. A long, warm and tender kiss.

question: Listen, you... Just then a LADY and her daughter hurry to the man, push- ing a trolley. Man turns to look at Ben. I'm sorry, my mistake. -- How's she doing?
answer: Better... She's waiting for you to ask her to come home.

question: I doubt it.
answer: Papa, I don't want to interfere...

question: Then don't.
answer: I know this is going to sound strange coming from me... I mean I haven't exactly been supportive for the past months... I can't say I agree with what you've done but I respect you for what you are... ON Johan listening. I'm just... destroyed by what's happening to us as a family.

question: Suzette...
answer: Please, Papa, for Mom's sake... For all of our sakes... Let's try and patch it up. Let me know if there's anything I can do to help.

question: Thanks. I'm glad you understand.
answer: I don't want to worry about you. That search, this vandalism, those shots... they're really after the evidence you've been accumulating ... Can I look after them for you, Papa?

question: You don't have to worry. They'll never find them.
answer: Where on earth do you keep them? ON Johan looking at Suzette then at Ben with concern.

question: Dr. Hassiem? I'm Ben Du Toit. I'm a friend of Gordon Ngubene's...
answer: The inquest is over, Mr. Du Toit.

question: Not for me, Doctor. I've got to know what happened to Gordon.
answer: I only came home yesterday. After three months in detention and now I'm banned and confined to the house. There's nothing I can do for you.

question: I know it may be painful to you, Doctor, but I need to talk to you.
answer: How can I be sure you weren't actually sent by them?

question: Ask Emily. Doctor, we are in the process of filing a civil claim. And your help is vital.
answer: Come in. Ben walks into the large living room, tastefully furnished. Sit down. Ben is still looking 'round at the opulence. He sits in a chair.

question: Thank you for inviting me in.
answer: What do you want to know?

question: Just one thing, Doctor. Why did you sign the State Pathologist's report on the autopsy if you drew up your own report as well?
answer: What makes you think I signed Dr. Jansen's report.

question: The report produced in court had both your signatures on it.
answer: Impossible.

question: What did you write in your report?
answer: Dr. Jansen and I didn't disagree on the facts. After all we examined the same body in the same time. But just on the interpretation. For example, if Gordon, had really been hanged, the marks on his throat would have been concentrated on the front. But in this case, the bruises were more obvious on the sides. Pause. Ben nods, silent. Something else really upset me, perhaps it isn't important.

question: What was it?
answer: You see, through a misunderstanding I arrived at the morgue too early for the autopsy. There wasn't a soul around except a young African attendant. When I told him I'd come for the autopsy, he let me in. The body was on the table dressed. I noticed blood on the clothes.

question: And then?
answer: As I examined the clothes more closely, a police-officer came in and said I wasn't allowed in the morgue before Dr. Jansen arrived. When I returned with Dr. Jansen, half an hour later, the body was naked.

question: Doctor, we've already got the African attendant's affidavit. He testified that Capt. Stolz ordered him to burn the clothes. Did you mention what you said in your report?
answer: Of course. I found it most odd.

question: Doctor Hassiem would you be prepared to put that in writing?
answer: Please excuse me for a minute. Ben watches him leave the room, the little girl following him. He gets up from the chair, walks to the window, glances through it, then steps to look at some family photographs on the mantlepiece. Amongst them a photograph of Dr. Hassiem before "Big Ben." Dr. Hassiem returns with a file, the daughter still following. This is my report. I only have one copy.

question: You have a copy of the report?
answer: I know how to hide things from the S.B., Mr. Du Toit. Ben congratulates him by a deep laughter. I hope you have as secure a place as I have.

question: I think so.
answer: Take a pew, man.

question: We have it, Stanley!
answer: Have what?

question: Hassiem's report. You know what that means, Stanley? Melanie arrives in two days. We'll have all the evidence. Everything is in place. We'll get them yet, especially Stolz.
answer: That's fantastic, man.

question: God! It's Johnson Seroke.
answer: Late at night. A knock on the door. He opened and five shots, point-blank range. Face, chest, stomach.

question: 'A police spokesman when questioned said
answer: What's the score? The nurse is detained; the mortuary attendant has disappeared; the police van driver who brought Jonathan to hospital is detained. Julius is in jail, and now Johnson dead.

question: Who's next on their secret list, I wonder? How much longer must the list grow of those who pay the price of our efforts to clear Gordon's name.
answer: Hey! Are you going soft, Lanie? We must keep going even more so now. And for every bloke who's going to die of bloody natural causes in their hands. And for our children's future.

question: I know. If I can no longer believe that right is on my side, if I can no longer believe in imperative to go on, what will become of me, Stanley? Ben looks at Johnson's picture again and shakes his head.
answer: We're all made of flesh and blood, Mr. Du Toit -- we've all got our flaws. And if a man likes to sample the grass on the other side of the fence, well, that's his own business. But it would be unpleasant if people found out about it, especially if he's a teacher.

question: You mean, if I cooperate, if I stop digging, embarrassing you, threatening you... these photographs will disappear.
answer: Let's just say I may be able to use my influence to make sure that a private indiscretion isn't used against you.

question: Suppose I refuse? Stolz looks past Ben.
answer: Is this your son?

question: Johan, leave us alone, please.
answer: Don't you think this business has gone long enough?

question: That's for you people to decide. Isn't it? I won't be blackmailed, Captain -- not even by you.
answer: Mind if I smoke? Now be honest. Has all the evidence you've been collecting in connection with Gordon Ngubene brought you closer to the truth you are looking for?

question: Yes, I think so and there's more to come. A pause.
answer: I really hoped we could talk man-to-man.

question: It's not possible, Captain. Not between you and me.
answer: It's high time, Mr. Du Toit, we allowed the dead to rest in peace. I'm offering you a chance.

question: You mean my very last chance?
answer: One never knows. It may not be important to you, but we have to survive.

question: If we can only survive through murder and torture, then we have forfeited our right to exist.
answer: Is that your final answer?

question: Before you go. I'll tell this, Captain. I have a pretty good idea of what I will eventually uncover. I mean the truth. And I won't allow anyone or anything to come between me and that truth.
answer: Here's my card -- my private line. If you should change your mind... Let's say before the end of the week?

question: Goodbye, Captain, and don't forgt the photograph. Stolz picks up the photograph and puts it into his briefcase.
answer: Be careful, Mr. Du Toit. There are people who can make things very difficult for you.

question: They are wasting their time. They just can't hurt me anymore. I trust you'll give them the message, Captain.
answer: A brandy, Papa?

question: A gin and tonic would be fine. Excuse me, I'm waiting for a lady with a red dress. Are there still, many people to come? Thank you. Just then an OFFICIAL walks out of the door. Ben hurries to him. Excuse me. I'm waiting for a passenger, Miss Bruwer. She's taking a rather long time to be cleared. Melanie Bruwer.
answer: Is there any other exit, Papa?

question: No. They have to collect their luggage and pass through customs.
answer: Maybe she can't find her bag.

question: That's possble.
answer: Afternoon, Meneer Du Toit. Johan, isn't it?

question: What now, Captain?
answer: Word came to me that you were asking after your very good friend, Miss Bruwer. You know, subersives come in all guises and can be very resourceful. Now let's take your friend, she has been using her privilege as a journalist to endanger the security of this country. But you know something else? She has been secretly holding a British passport. A South African passport and a British pasport. Now you tell me, where is her patriotism? Her allegiance? The minister telexed to the immigration officers here declaring her an undesirable immigrant. So she is being put on the first available plane to London. This must be heart- breaking for you. Good afternoon, Meneer Du Toit, Johan. Stolz walks back.

question: Let's go home, Johan.
answer: I don't understand, Papa...

question: I'll explain later.
answer: I took it out. Hide it in my secret place.

question: Thank you, son. You did a man's job. CUT TO:
answer: Somebody has dropped it through the door.

question: Thank you.
answer: I'm nearly ready, Papa. Ben examines the unstamped envelope with his address, with curiosity then opens it. The contents is Wellington's affidavit.

question: Wellington's affidavit! Good old Melanie!
answer: What's happened, man?

question: It's you. It was a bomb.
answer: And the papers?

question: Don't worry. Safe. Thanks to Johan. Incidentally, I have Wellington's affidavit. Melanie found him. She's being deported. The official reason is that she possessed a British passport. I don't know how she managed to smuggle the envelope to me.
answer: Man, it's all happening! Like a joint?

question: No, thanks. What's so funny?
answer: They drop the bomb on you! Ben walks up to him puts his hand on his shoulder. There's an understanding trace of a smile on his face.

question: How are you, Suzette?
answer: Okay, Papa.

question: Would you like a drink?
answer: No, thanks. Without taking his eyes off her, he takes a brown envelope from a chair and pushes it slowly towards the uncomfor- table Suzette. She picks up the envelope. I have to go, Papa.
